Here is what I have heard folks  call this so called "transit"---all heard at the transit center in Eugene: bum trains,  shame train, limo for lushes, a place to hit up (shoot heroin), trash stash (alluding to the allure of the riders), the mission migrator (all the bums headed to the Eugene Mission between 5:30 and 6:00 when they have curfew), the loony bin; getaway car; and so on.   The U of O students get free passes and the bums get free bus passes.  I have to tell you, I am not paying $65 a month to ride with junkies and bums, petty little criminals, a drunk puking into the seat next to him or the guy passed out in the back, with five garbage bags at his feet blocking the aisles.  After working all day,  it would not be worth it. Nope, I will drive.

Want the Permanent Fund reform bill to pass?  It's easy.  Kill the oil tax credits.  

While your argument regarding priorities may be sound, the political reality is that the tax credit ripoff is hugely unpopular.  I know of no one who agrees with it.  Killing the tax credits is easy.  No big agonizing over what budget cuts to make or if/how taxes should be levied.  Kill the tax credits and enough people will support enough legislators.

Don't kill them now and they never will be killed.  Once the legislators get their hands on the PF, why would they do any of the other things that need to be done.  The money we pay out on them will be compounded forever as well.   

I have no problem using the PF.  But it'll be a cold day in hell before I'll support relinquishing any part of the PFD just to hand it over to the oil companies.  Most people I talk to feel the same way, regardless how they feel about budget cuts or taxes.  

The tax credits are toxic.  Kill them.

In 1946 Julius Streicher, editor of the Nazi newspaper 'Der Stuermer', was convicted by the Nuremberg Tribunal of inciting hatred against German Jews and executed.  So far as is known, he committed no violent act during the Third Reich's hegemony, nor--according to his trial testimony--ever advocated violence in his publication

Realize that the unfunded liability is mostly not about the retirement system at all.  It is about massive errors by actuaries and bad behavior by politicians.  Cleaning it up is a multi-billion dollar mess that local agencies are responsible for technically.  The amount of money can potentially swamp their budgets.  The state SHOULD be covering all of it, but they "pass" money back to local governments and school districts and then "take" it again.  This artificially inflates the numbers Mr. Boyle likes to use, suggesting the school boards actually see and use that money.  They don't.
This is weaseling back on their own problem, dumping it to locals, and they have to do stuff like that late in the session without input, because the more people get a chance to understand it, the less they like legislators.
